results.title: Shifting to Governing, Taliban Will Name Supreme Afghan Leader
results.abstract: Facing immense challenges in a devastated country, and a hard transition from war to administration, the Islamist movement is preparing to name a new, theocratic government.

results.title: It’s Election Season in Germany. No Charisma, Please!
results.abstract: The race to replace Chancellor Angela Merkel after 16 years in office is the tightest in years. But the two leading candidates are anything but exciting, and that’s how Germans like it.

multimedia.caption: Olaf Scholz, center left, of the Social Democrats, and Armin Laschet, center, of the Christian Democratic Union. Their race has become a contest to see who can best channel Chancellor Angela Merkel’s aura of stability and calm.
multimedia.copyright: Pool photo by Marius Becker

results.title: Covert Evacuations and Planned Demolitions: How the C.I.A. Left Its Last Base in Afghanistan

results.title: Gail Omvedt, 80, Dies; India Became Her Home, the Caste System Her Cause
results.abstract: An American-born sociologist, she moved to India in the 1970s, helped pioneer the study of castes and drew attention to the lives of the country’s most oppressed.

multimedia.caption: The scholar and activist Gail Omvedt in 1980 at a national conference on women’s rights in Bombay (later renamed Mumbai). She drew attention to members of an oppressed caste once commonly called the untouchables.
multimedia.copyright: via Prachi Patankar

results.title: Another Hidden Covid Risk: Lingering Kidney Problems

results.title: Bank of England Removes Art of Leaders Linked to Slave Trade
results.abstract: Oil paintings and portraits depicting seven leading figures at the bank have been removed because of their connections to slavery.

multimedia.caption: The Bank of England building in London. The bank apologized last year for the role of some top officials in the slave trade.

results.title: European Court Faults Russia in High-Profile Murder Case
results.abstract: The European Court of Human Rights ruled that Russia failed to investigate the abduction and murder of Natalya Estemirova, a human rights researcher, but did not directly implicate the state in her killing.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Activists holding pictures of Natalya Estemirova in July 2010, a year after the human rights activist was killed in Russia.

results.title: 6 Sentenced to Death in Bangladesh for Killing of Gay Rights Activist
results.abstract: The activist Xulhaz Mannan, who had started a gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender magazine, was hacked to death in a machete attack in 2016.
results.byline: By Saif Hasnat and Suhasini Raj

multimedia.caption: A memorial in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in 2017, a year after the killing of the gay rights activist Xulhaz Mannan, also referred to as Julhas Mannan, and his friend Mahbub Rabbi Tonoy.

results.title: A Fellini Museum, as Lavish as His Movies
results.abstract: The exhibition spaces, which recently opened in Rimini, celebrate one of Italy’s most famous directors. But to some citizens, it puts tourism over local needs.

results.title: 70 percent of adults in the European Union have been fully vaccinated.
results.abstract: After a fumbling start, the European Union overtook the United States in vaccinations last month.

results.title: An Experimental H.I.V. Vaccine Fails in Africa
results.abstract: Researchers ended a large trial in South Africa after finding that an experimental vaccine offered little protection.

results.title: The police set up checkpoints outside New Zealand’s largest city.
results.abstract: The aim is to limit travel out of Auckland, which will remain under the highest level of Covid restrictions for two weeks after rules are eased in neighboring regions.
